title: Six ways the weather can scar , shift , and snap the Earth itself
message:
Ferocious storms are capable of changing communities for generations, leaving behind everlasting reminders of their raw power.
There’s no shortage of ways that the weather can alter the very ground beneath our feet.
Here are six events that can scar, shift, and crumble the Earth itself.
A tornado scar can last for years or even decades after particularly strong tornadoes.
The above satellite image shows the immediate aftermath of the EF-5 tornado that ripped through Joplin, Missouri, back in May 2011.

title: Edgecombe County residents concerned about rising water levels following Debby
message:
EDGECOMBE COUNTY, N.C. (WITN) - Residents across Eastern North Carolina are still trying to recover from Tropical Storm Debby’s heavy rains and winds, but many are concerned the rising river levels could cause more problems.
After their experience living through Hurricane Floyd in 1999, every time there’s a storm, they get nervous about its impact on their Edgecombe County home.
“I think, ‘Oh lord, it’s going to happen again,’ but the water rises and nobody comes out to check on us.”After Debby made landfall in Eastern Carolina Thursday, the Tar River’s water levels have risen and flooded over many properties and roads.
The roads are back open, but resident Dylan Everette lives off of Highway 111 and says as the river levels go up, flooding could happen in the area again.
“We’re a little bit worried about what’s going to come next.”The National Weather Service has issued a flood warning for Edgecombe County until further notice.

title: Debby finally moves out of the US , though power outages , flooding risks remain
message:
Nearly 170,000 customers in Ohio, New York, Pennsylvania and Vermont had no electricity Saturday afternoon according to PowerOutage.us, and some utilities said restoration could take days.
More than half the outages were in Ohio, where Debby-related storms including tornadoes blew through the northeastern part of the state on Wednesday.
They urged people to document damage before beginning cleanup efforts and to send them any images of the flooding.
About 19,000 Vermont homes and businesses remained without power Saturday afternoon, down from more than 44,000 the previous day.
"There is widespread, extensive damage in many locations," said Mike Burke, vice president of operations at Green Mountain Power.

title: Debby finally moves out of the US , though some flooding risk and power outages remain
message:
Nearly 170,000 customers in Ohio, New York, Pennsylvania and Vermont had no electricity Saturday afternoon, according to PowerOutage.us, and some utilities said restoration could take days.
More than half the outages were in Ohio, where Debby-related storms including tornadoes blew through the northeastern part of the state on Wednesday.
Some of the worst flash flooding in New York happened in villages and hamlets in a largely rural area south of the Finger Lakes.
About 19,000 Vermont homes and businesses remained without power Saturday afternoon, down from more than 44,000 the previous day.
“There is widespread, extensive damage in many locations,” said Mike Burke, vice president of operations at Green Mountain Power.

title: Light earthquake , 4 . 7 mag strikes near Panguna in Papua New Guinea
message:
A light earthquake magnitude 4.7 (ml/mb) strikes 186 km NW of Panguna, Papua New Guinea (116 miles) on Sunday.
The earthquake occurred at a depth of 132.25 km (82 miles) below the earth’s surface.
Exact time and date of earthquake 11/08/24 / 2024-08-11 01:26:41 / August 11, 2024 @ 1:26 am UTC/GMT.
A tsunami warning has not been issued (Does not indicate if a tsunami actually did or will exist).
Read more about the earthquake, Seismometer information, Date-Time, Location, Distances, Parameters and details about this quake, recorded: 186 km NW of Panguna, Papua New Guinea.

title: Light earthquake , 4 . 3 mag has occurred near Acajutla in El Salvador
message:
A light earthquake magnitude 4.3 (ml/mb) strikes 44 kilometers (27 miles) from Acajutla in El Salvador on Saturday.
The 4.3-magnitude earthquake has occurred at 19:06:17 / 7:06 pm (local time epicenter).
The earthquake occurred at a depth of 67.449 km (42 miles) below the earth’s surface.
Close country/countries that might be effected, El Salvador (c. 6 052 000 pop).
Read more about the earthquake, Seismometer information, Distances, Parameters, Date-Time, Location and details about this quake, that has occurred near: 44 km WSW of Acajutla, El Salvador.

title: Light earthquake , 4 . 8 mag strikes near Miyazaki in Japan
message:
A light earthquake magnitude 4.8 (ml/mb) strikes 18 kilometers (11 miles) from Miyazaki in Japan on Saturday.
Event ids that are associated to the earthquake: us6000njf2.
Id of event: us6000njf2.
The earthquake occurred at a depth of 46.188 km (29 miles) below the earth’s surface.
Read more about the earthquake, Seismometer information, Date-Time, Location, Distances, Parameters and details about this quake, recorded: 18 km ESE of Miyazaki, Japan.

title: Marlboro Co . leaders monitoring flooding after Tropical Storm Debby
message:
Communities across the Pee Dee are picking up the pieces after Tropical Storm Debby impacted the area this week.
Town leaders in Marlboro County said although water levels are dropping, flooding has not completely receded.
Director of Operations Jamal Campbell told ABC15 that with high temperatures coming back, leaders hope to see flooding decrease.
Residents were staying at Marlboro County High School after several people evacuated their homes.
Leaders said it was all hands-on deck for emergency crews through tropical storm Debby ensuring the safety of all residents.

title: Debby leaves US , flooding and power outages remain
message:
Nearly 170,000 customers in Ohio, New York, Pennsylvania and Vermont had no electricity on Saturday afternoon, according to PowerOutage.us, and some utilities said restoration could take days.
More than half the outages were in Ohio, where Debby-related storms including tornadoes blew through the northeastern part of the state on Wednesday.

title: Record high flooding impacts local crops
message:
SAVANNAH, Ga. (WTOC) - Over the past week, tropical storm Debby hit our area hard with record high flooding.
That flooding has not only impacted homes and infrastructure, but also crops.
WTOC spoke with a Forsyth Farmer’s Market representative to share how Coastal Empire and Lowcountry farmers have been affected.
A representative from the Forsyth Farmer’s Market said some farmers have already told her how their crops have been ruined for the season.
Basically, the crops, a lot of the crops, got washed out, literally,” said Interim Executive Director of Forsyth Farmers Market, Tina Saxe.

title: First Alert Weather : Good timing for dry weather
message:
Breezy and dry conditions were a welcome relief for Western New York.
The remnants of Tropical Storm Debby brought flooding rain, which produced significant flooding for communities east of the Genesee Valley.
Portions of Wayne, Ontario, Yates, and Steuben counties measured between 1 and 4 inches of tropical rainfall.
Unfortunately, the dry weather will not last for the rest of the weekend.
It will turn breezy again with the high temperature in the middle 70s.

title: Remnants of Debby exit as another tropical wave brews over central Atlantic
message:
Remnants of Debby exit as another tropical wave brews over central AtlanticDespite Debby being downgraded to a post-tropical storm as it tracked north, it still brought a plethora of impacts across the Northeast on Friday.
While Debby departs the nation, all eyes are on another tropical wave over the central tropical Atlantic.
Parts of southeastern New Jersey reported over 8 inches -- Pennington, New Jersey, reported 8.67 inches of rain and Hopewell Township, New Jersey, reported 8.24 inches.
While multiple Tornado Warnings were issued across the Northeast, only one tornado was confirmed in New Paltz, New York.
Wind gusts ranged between 40 to 60 mph across portions of the Delmarva up through eastern Pennsylvania, New York and New Jersey.

title: Richmond Hill residents try to stay afloat amid historic flood levels
message:
RICHMOND HILL, Ga. (WTOC) - Debby may be gone, but Bryan County residents are still dealing with the storm’s fallout.
WTOC visited parts of Richmond Hill where people have been experiencing some of the worst flooding they’ve ever seen.
Residents are doing what they can to stay afloat as floodwaters threaten their homes and safety.
If people just don’t need their sandbags, we’re collecting them and bringing them to the people that actually do need them,” said Richmond Hill resident, Fallon Prisuta.
Flooding throughout Richmond Hill has already reached historic levels, and until rivers like the Ogeechee crest, more flooding is likely.

title: Snakes , baby squirrels , bird : Grand Strand snake chaser sees increase in animal relocation calls after Debby
message:
Snake chaser Hayden Cavender said this is due to higher wind and water levels after Debby.
He told WMBF News after storms, he expects to be busier, with calls increasing by 15 to 20 percent.
Cavender told WMBF News he has removed four cottonmouth snakes from the neighborhood in the last two days.
He wants people to be vigilant, as some of these snakes are venomous, but not to panic if they do come across a snake.
“They won’t come and outright try to grab you or try to attack you or try to bite you,” said Cavender.

title: Sarasota County opens resource center for residents impacted by Debby
message:
We take care of our people and that's really what we're striving our best to do," Sarasota County Public Information Officer Cole Washko said.
That's why on Saturday, more than 20 local and state agencies, including Sarasota County, opened a multi-agency resource center.
We want to be that answer and as well as some of the local and state agencies that are here.
Along with basic needs, residents can also get long-term support like help with navigating insurance claims or signing up for flood insurance.
We just want to encourage people to come out and get the help that they deserve and need," Washko said.
